seven-headed, δράκοντες Dam. Isid. 67, cf. Pr. 265.

seven times, Pi. O. 13.40, Ar. Lys. 698, etc.:— poet. ἑπτάκι Simon. 156, A.R. 3.861, etc.: also in later Prose, SIG 1068.8 ( Patmos, iii/ii B. C.), Iamb. in Nic. p.17 P.:— Lacon. ἑπτάκιν IG 5(1).213.16 (V B.C.).
seventy thousand, Hdt. 4.86, Plu. Demetr. 28.
seven thousand, Hdt. 2.43, etc.; ἑπτασχίλιαι (sic) PSI 3.250 (iii/iv A. D.).

with seven couches or beds, οἶκος Phryn. Com.66, X. Smp. 2.18 ; κοιτών Callix. I; and without οἶκος, Tim.Com.I ; θὲς ἑπτάκλινον place seven seats, Eub. 121 ; τὸ δέρμα κατέχει εἰς ἑ. ἀποταθέν provides sitting-room for seven, Arist. HA 630a22 : hence, as a measure of area, Ph. Bel. 80.48.
seven hundred, Hdt. 2.140, etc.
seven-hundredth, Archim. Aren. 1.10, Cleom. 2.1, D.L. 1.24.
holding seven cotylae, λήκυθος Ar. Fr. 472.
with seven rays, of the sun, Jul. Or. 5.172d, Procl. in Ti. 1.34D.
seven-toned, φόρμιγξ Pi. P. 2.70.
of seven members, περίοδος Sch. Ar. Ra. 221.
with seven lobes, Ar.Byz. Epit. 90.16.
of seven lances, i.e. seven bodies of spearmen, στόλος S. OC 1305.
= Lat. septimontium, Gloss.
seven-hilled, ἄστυ, of Rome, Cic. Att. 6.5.2, AP 14.121 ( Metrod.), cf. Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.280d.
having seven members, Procl. in Ti. 2.209D.
having seven parts, ψυχῆς τὸ ἄλογον ἑ. Ph. 1.45, cf. Procl. in Ti. 2.209D.

definition: ἑπταμέριον, τό, dub. sens. in PMag.Berol. 1.201.
ἑπταμήκης κύκλος, dub. sens. in Call. Iamb. 1.126 (cf. D.S. 10.6); perh. referring to the Pythagorean harmony of the planetary spheres.

children.definition: born in the seventh month, Cic. Att. 10.18.1, J. AJ 5.11.4, Placit. 5.18.5:—also ἑπτα-μήνιος, ον, Theol.Ar. 48.
a seven months’ child, Hp. Septim. passim ; τίκτειν τινὰ ἑπτάμηνον, τίκτειν ἑπτάμηνα [ τέκνα], Hdt. 6.69, cf. Arist. HA 584a36.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἑπτάμηνος, ἡ, a space of seven months, Placit. 5.18.1, cf. IG 12(1).53 ( Rhodes).
mother of seven children, LXX 4 Ma. 16.24.
seven-stringed, Luc. Astr. 10 ; κιθάρη AP 9.250 ( Honest.).
weighing seven minae, Hsch. s.v. μολβίς.
arc of seven degrees, Paul.Al. H. I.
= Lat. Septempagi, Plu. Rom. 25.
with seven wicks, λύχνος PMag.Lond. 121.593 : Subst. -μυξος (sc. λύχνος), ὁ, seven-branched candlestick, JHS 28.195 ( Side).
with seven recesses, σπέος Call. Del. 65 : title of work by Pherecyd.Syr.

definition: ἑπτάνευρον, τό, prob. f.l. for ἑπτάπλευρον II, Paul.Aeg. 7.17, Apul. Herb. I.

children.definition: = Lat. septimontium, Gloss.
= Lat. septunx, Gloss.
seven palms long, S.E. M. 9.321:—early Att. ἑπτα-πάλαστος IG 1(2).373.237.

definition: ἑπτάπεκτος ἡ βαθείας τρίχας ἔχουσα, Hsch. ( -ιος cod.), cf. Suid.; ἡ δυναμένη ἑπτάκις τμηθῆναι, EM 368.11.

children.definition: seven plethra large, Ἄρης Nonn. D. 36.14.
seven cubits long, Hdt. 1.68, Pl. Ep. 363a, etc.; seven cubits tall, ἀνήρ J. AJ 18.4.5.
with seven revolutions, v.l. in Secund. Sent. I.
multiply seven times, Dam. Pr. 98, Hero *Geom. 17.7: hence, ἑπτα-πλᾰσιασμός, ὁ, ib. 3 3:
sevenfold, -πλασίῳ φαυλότερος Pl. Ep. 332a, cf. Iamb. in Nic. p.102 P. Adv. -ιως LXX Ps. 11(12).6, al.

definition: ἑπταπλασίων, ον, gen. ονος, = foreg., Orib. Fr. 90, Suid.

children.definition: having seven ribs, Arist. HA 493b15.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἑπτά-πλευρον, τό, = ἀρνόγλωσσον, Dsc. 2.126.
sevenfold, ἑπταπλᾶ ἀνταποδώσει σοι LXX Si. 32 ( 35). 13.
seven feet long, θρῆνυς Il. 15.729 ; ἄξων Hes. Op. 424.
containing seven cities: ἑ. μεσάτη ἤπειρος, of Egypt, D.P. 251.

with seven tracks or paths, τείρεα, of the planets, h.Hom. 8.7; Πλειάς or Πελειάς, E. IA 7, Or. 1005 (both anap.); Πληϊὰς ἑ. Epigr.Gr. 223.4 ( Milet.); seven-mouthed, of the Nile, Mosch. 2.51, D.P. 264.
seven feet long, σκιά Ar. Fr. 675, cf. IG 1(2).372.19, Anon. in Tht. 34.25.
having seven feet, πολύπους Ael. Fr. 143.

definition: ἑπτάπτυχος, ον, glosson ἑπταβόειος, Sch. D Il. 7.220.

children.definition: with seven gates, epith. of Boeotian Thebes (cf. ἑκατόμπυλος), Il. 4.406, Od. 11.263, B. 18.47, Anaxandr. 41.21, cf. A. Th. 165 (lyr.), S. Ant. 119 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: ἑ. κλῖμαξ stairway symbolizing the ascent of the soul through the seven planetary spheres, Cels. ap. Origenes Cels. 6.22 (prob. for ὑψί-).
seven-towered, of Boeotian Thebes, E. Ph. 245 (lyr.), etc.: metaph., εὐλογιστία LXX 4 Ma. 13.7.
with seven flames or wicks, λύχνος SIG 1106.119 ( Cos, iv/iii B. C.).
of seven ἄρουραι (q.v.), PTeb. 13 Intr. (ii B. C.), cf. 128 (ii B. C.):
holder of seven ἄρουραι, PTeb. 60.30 (ii B. C.), etc.: ἑπτάρουρον, τό,
plot of seven ἄρουραι, PFay. 118.25 (ii A. D.).
with seven channels, Νεῖλος ἑπτάρους A. Fr. 300.
period of seven days, Arist. HA 553a3 (pl.).

children.label: II
children.definition: period of seven years, Syria 5.338, etc.

children.label: III
children.definition: the number seven, Theol.Ar. 43, Nicom. Ar. 1.16.
of seven times, in metre, συζυγίαι Heph. 11.5, cf. 12.1, Aristid.Quint. 1.14.
seven stades long, διῶρυξ Scymn. 649 ; πορθμός Str. 2.5.19 ; χῶμα J. AJ 12.2.13 : Subst., τὸ ἑ. space of seven stades, Str. 2.5.22.
of seven stars, Eratosth. Cat. 14, Gal. 9.935.
seven-mouthed, πύλαι ἑ., of Boeotian Thebes, E. Supp. 401 ; ἑ. πύργωμα, πόλισμα, Id. Ph. 287, Ba. 919 ; πύλαι S. Fr. 773 ; of rivers, Str. 4.1.8, 7.3.15.
weighing seven talents, λίθος Them. Or. 23.284b.
seven outlets of the walls of Thebes, A. Th. 285.
book in seven volumes, Sidon.Apoll. Ep. 5.15.
seven-toned, φόρμιγξ Terp. 5 ; γᾶρυς B. Scol.Oxy. 1361 Fr. 1.2 ; λύρα Ion Eleg.3.3 ; χέλυς E. Alc. 446 (lyr.).
sevenfold shining, Orph. H. 7.8.
drug compounded of seven ingredients, Aët. 15.26.
